newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.
newsitem.headline: S.Africa rand/bonds closing report.

text.p: Short-covering by local banks after a hefty institutional order earlier hauled bond yields to their lowest levels in 16 months on Friday.

After drifting between 14.46 and 14.37 percent for much of the trading day, yields suddenly gapped to an intraday low of 14.30 percent -- its lowest level since February 20 last year -- shortly before 1400 GMT.
"During lunch a local institution took out a few banks. Then when the banks tried to cover this afternoon, there seemed to be a bit of a tight squeeze...the guys were caught short," a trader said.

Dealers said the demand from institutions in general over the last few days appeared to stem from a shift in sentiment away from the money market, where short-term rates have been falling steadily, towards bonds.

"Institutions are piling in at the moment after thinking that the money market was a good place to be all year," one said, adding that chart signals on the long-end were extremely bullish and that there was a general dearth of stock in the market.
A broker also noted that there were positive expectations in the market of bullish money supply and private sector credit extension data -- due for release at 1500 GMT.

Economists have called for a 15.19 percent increase in May money supply growth from a preliminary 15.44 percent in April, while growth in credit extended to the private sector was expected to rise 16.56 percent year-on-year from 16.95 percent before.
Dealers said barring any negative surprises from the Reserve Bank data, the market was likely to extend its gains further on Monday.
